comment: I loved the scents this whiskey had. Strong caramel with berries.  I just didn't like the finish to much.  Very long...
Great whisky. Very smooth. A little pricey, but it doesn't disappoint.
Tastes like a bourbon. Carmel and fruit, good spice and heart
The first whisky where the scent of alcohol overpowers the flavors. Interestingly, this didn't impact the tasting. Which is delicious.

I was having this while watching last night's Walking Dead.  So...my opinions may be slightly skewed,  Was a gut wrenching episode.  Okay..so...I love the aroma on the nose--a sweet caramel with some floral notes.  But, I think it falls short on the palette, just lacks the depth and complexity.  Maybe an age thing?  Finish is slightly bitter, almost like dried thyme.   Not bad.  But, nothing to write home about either.

Very impressive offering.  Best to drink neat - adding water brings the smoke out. 
Nose: honey, mixed berry, very floral - no citrus 
Palate: on the tonge - 2.5/4 body, oily, does not change from palate. 
Finish: very wet. Stays with you. alcohol progresses forward.

I got a bottle of this for my birthday, except it doesn't say single malt. Anyone els have a bottle like that? Anyways, this is still a very pleasant dram. Reminds me of a lighter version of the Yellow Spot.

Nose: orange, pineapple, light caramel, vanilla, faint wood. 
Palate: pineapple, orange, orange zest, vanilla forward, young bite, slight peppercorn, wood, caramel finish slight dark chocolate on the finish with oxidation
The nose is nice and I can also pick up the green tea and the finish is short. A good drink but the price maybe too high.
Nice for beginners but a bit less punch for islay drinker.

[Whiskey Live Paris 2015] Tried this after the Vinho Soloist.  Maybe a little unfait because that one was friggin amazing.  This dram, not so interesting, especially for the fact it's over 70$ a bottle!
Surprisingly good, one of my favourites
We have Podium in collection. Purple bottle
Nice. I feel that I want it to develop more. Like the sweetness. Tiny hint of smoke at the end. Maybe too tiny.

After reading a heap of good reviews, I had the opportunity to try this one.
While not a bad whiskey, it didn't impress me, it reminds me a bit of the Yamazaki, which I'm also not a huge fan of.
Very fruity and very delicious.  Definitely worth the money.

On the nose, beautifully floral and fresh. A simplicity that was a pleasant surprise. Rounded on the taste, with a dry and sweet sensation. The finish is a little bit spicy, but short, shy and disappointing. Overall a good whisky. Not amazing, but good.
Safe but superb, fruity, delicate liquid with a smooth but indistinct finish

From the award-winning distillery in Taiwan, Kavalan Single Malt is their entry-level bottling. Being matured in six different cask types, the nose is reminiscent of a quality Blended Scotch. Very fruity with ripe oranges, mango and pineapple at first, the aroma turns more floral and honeyed upon adding a little water. Werther's Original drops, maple syrup and measured oak influence characterize the rather simple taste of this young malt. The finish is quick, chocolaty and slightly bitter. An interesting but very 'engineered' whisky with a hefty price tag.

RATING: 3.2/5.0 stars ≙ 81 pts → AVERAGE [+]
A slow sipper. Pleasant enough but lacks a bit of depth
Best taste and very smooth. Always get it.

Quite enjoyable I must say. The sort of whisky I could describe as a Lowland with touches of fruit and sherry. At 40% ABV it's a tad flat and weak, however still quite flavorful. The nose and palate are, again, sherry with hints of dried fruits and honey - there's even an ever so slight touch of mangoes (quite nice). The body is regretfully not there and the finish is as short as I have ever come across for a whisky. In sum: I liked it, and would perhaps even buy it for those guests I may have who are not naturally inclined to drinking whisky.
10/16 Hook & Ladder w Charles. Too oaky and young.  Unbalanced.
It's pretty good. Nothing that's going to blow your socks off, but definitely makes me want to explore more of their offerings.

I didn't enjoy it, I had waited a year to try this, but it was spicy, overly dry, herby and a miserably short finish. The sweet oiliness from the heat and the coast of the distillery and the sherry cask doesn't mix with the dry, lemony spice from the bourbon and new American oak cask just doesn't work for me. Then I found the amazing Kavalan Port Cask and I finally understood why Kavalan is so popular.

If I had to compare this to a wine, it would be like an aged chardonnay - buttery, oaky notes of vanilla and spice, plus tropical fruit and honey roasted nuts both on the nose and palate. It's a good dram, competing for me with the Ex-Bourbon Cask and Concertmaster (port cask) for top honors.
very light and fruity, easy to drink. tasty but not super complex

My simple reaction: why? This particular malt is just too similar to Scottish brands and comes across as a cross between Dalwhinnie and a light Dalmore. Those reviewers struggling to find a unique nose or palate are right I think. In my humble opinion I cannot taste the strand of mango that some seem to detect. What a shame. Is it there? Help! Given it is around $70 it simply cannot compare to either a Dalmore or Dalwhinnie 15 year old which are roughly the same price or less. Hope you have a better experience. 86 is a bit too high a score. Hud
Very smooth. Sweet, fruity, smoky, spicy
Enjoyable after a few sips. Vanilla, slightly oily and a finish with a touch of burn. If it was smoother it would be a 4
Aroma of vanilla, flowers, some maple syrup. Tastes little rough, sweet, heavy oak presence
Had side-by-side with the King Car. This was bolder and less refined, but I liked it better.
Strong melon notes on the nose, reminiscent of Midori. That carries over onto the tongue. Melon, sweet, some slight wood spice. More Sherry notes in the aftertaste. Smooth and pleasant. 7/29/17
Quite herbal, with a bit of smoke and sweetness. Not my thing.

Nose: floral, nutty, dried fruit, apricot, cherry, menthol, almond liquor, ginseng.
Palette: cherry, sherry, black pepper, other spices, creamy and nutty.
Finish: bit of smoke, almond, and fruits, ginseng.
Way to harsh. Not as smooth as other whisky they produced, e.g conductor.
Loved it and would seek it out again. Advent 2017

75, a 3.8 out of 5. Kavalan's single malt offering blends a Scotch's diligence and a longwinded Kentucky hug. The Taiwanese distillery is struggling to find markey share in the shadow of the Japanese whiskey boom, but not from a lack of quality. While the take home price of a bottle in the states is not likely worth it, Kavalan does show off an impressive mutation in style. A less than exciting nose gives birth to a palate of cinnamon apples and sandalwood  crescendoing into a long dip in a pool of honey. The nose and the palate are mere stepping stones to a beautiful finish from an abnormally young whiskey. I'm intrigued by the emerging region's interpretation of the water of life. I will reevaluate in a few years. Definitely worth the dram, maybe not the bottle: at least not yet.
3.5 as a gift from a friend
Ronak had this at whiskey library in Portland
The nose reminds me of a fruity cheesecake. Vanilla, peach, mango & creamy biscuit notes. Palate has mango, cinnamon, oak spice. Finishes on white pepper, vanilla and apples.
not good. super thin mouth feel and no linger

Nose: very fruity. Mangoes and pears with a hint of vanilla. 
Palate: meaty and savory with mangoes leading the way with spices bringing up the rear
Finish: complex. Dry yet oily. Lingering on the tongue
Interesting! smoky and extremely salty. if it wasn't for the salt, I'd be down with it, but that salt really kills it.
MANGO finish, fruity body, want to try an older or higher proof version
The dark side of Mango. Might not be your best friend after the first sip, but this dram could be a slowly growing long lasting friendship.
Goes down easily, smooth, but a little insipid
mango solidly coming through. quite rough, but pretty good
Good solid whiskey. Heats up in your throat/chest, but has a really nice oily texture that I enjoyed.
I have to bump this up to 4/5 after finishing the heel of this bottle. The mangos were smacking me in the mouth and it was fantastic.
Alright, not really worth it, other than to try a whisky from Taiwan.
Rich and sweet with a nice smooth finish.

Liked the tropical fruits. Smooth, easy drinking. Not sure why others felt it was harsh. I didn’t get any peat or smoke. Young, and somewhat underpowered, though. And a bit pricey at ¥5,000 ($45), same as my regular dram, Ardbeg 10.

5/29/19 
Hosted at my house 
Tasted like I’m drinking a raisin...

I just have kavalan for the first time and I like it alot.  it's smooth and really easy to drink, not super complex or anything.  just very good and balanced.  it reminded me of the first time I had Yamazaki in terms of the clean, neat finish.   less fruit than Yamazaki, more vanilla and sweet notes.
This is young whisky but it’s still warm and flavorful, rich and oaky. 88

Nose: Dried fruits(raisins), roasted nuts, honeydew melon, lightly floral, bright citrus, astringent sweetness.

Palate: Big, rich waves of Sherry right off the back. Washing out into bright grape sweetness. Roasted almonds and chocolate-covered marzipan. The finish is short and quick, coming on with pink peppercorns and rapidly fading into a dry sweet end.

Thoughts: It's cool to see the effects a hot humid climate can have on a whisky. There is a lot to like here for such a young Malt. The tropical melon notes, the bright citrus, and honey. There's a delicate floral note both in nose and palate that have a definitive tropical style to them. All in all this whisky is easy drinking, and something decidedly different from the usual Scotch style offerings. Novices and seasoned veterans alike will find something to like here.

My first Taiwanese whiskey.  This is one good, classic single malt.  Does have a bit of mustiness about the flavor but not so much so as to turn me off of this whiskey.  A bit expense, but worth the splurge once in a while.
Notes of tropical fruit, smooth, thin

You get more bourbon sugary notes than sherry notes in there on the nose also with a little hint of beautiful floral smell.
On the palate it's all very gentle sugary with now much stronger sherry dry fruit hit you like a wave. Then suddenly a jet boat full of lemon zest and wood spicy notes swish across the middle, and drop 1 or 2 of peaches on the way.
You will finish with a bit of dry wood bitterness like a black tea lingers in your mouth.

Simple but not boring whisky.

Could be Scottish on the nose and palate. 

Good everyday's one.
Thick, honey-ish, vanilla-ish...  no sherry.  Very good.
Floral nose, floral mid palate short finish, front heat
Really complex and flavorful. Peppery with a floral finish.

Caramel, apple, pear, vanilla, oak, smoke
Great
Would buy
Herbs on the nose, nuts at the end.
Green tea, fruity, not long finish
Floral and sweet fuits. Easy to drink.
Has a very slight pet taste at the end
Solid, sits between a "glen" and an islay.  Closer to the "glen".

I want to believe that i have a moral obligation to rate whiskies not for what i like but for what they are. This is one of those cases. My first Kavalan, the taiwanese awarded malt, gave me some interesting things to write about and a moral dilemma, whether to give it a 5.0 or not, because i really think it is a masterpiece, just not MY masterpiece.

Bottled at 57.8%abv, with a chesnut oloroso sherry color. Yes, it is a cask strenght, yes it hits your face like a nuclear spice bomb.

On the nose it might just be one of the best drams ever, so complex and rich, sweet and wonderful. So many notes, so much going on there. Fresh banana, vanilla, cinnamon, banana ice cream, prunes, lemon, coconut (first time i find this on a dram), pine tree, pancakes, cocoa powder, an dim blackberry marmalade note,  are the aromas i got from this baby. Truly a work of art and i believe it only has 5yo of maturation, but, due to Taiwan's tropical climate, the process is faster. On the nose it fools you as if it were a cold dram, that is a feeling i got from it.

On the palate is just too strong to have it neat. I drank it all neat and it was great and also difficult. A very dim caramel and apricot note starts the experience to turn into an inmidiate NUCLEAR SPICE BOMB. Very hot, a lot of barley and cereal notes, there are some oranges there but hidden, ashes, tobbacco, pepper, cinnamon, clove, vanilla cake, all spice is the main note. It is so powerful that in my first sip it forced me to involuntary close one eye. It is a full palate experience, the finish is ETERNAL, with a banana aftertaste (typical of bourbons) and there is always a dim sherry note coming and going on the nose and palate. After two sips you get the hang of it and learn how to taste it without dying because of its power. It is not a punch in the face, its like Mike Tyson's punch in the face, and for me, that is not too appealing. I am not a big fan of cask strenght whiskies because of that. If it is not enjoyable easily, why even bother. This super complex dram is maybe too powerful for me, but i recognize that it is a work of art. 

Overall i give this baby a 97 over 100, and i know most experienced whisky lovers will give it a 100 without doubt. Cheers.
